Chapter 7: PÄramitÄ of Patience
At that time, the Buddha BhagavÄn had already revealed the pÄramitÄ of pure precepts like this.
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

How should bodhisattvas cultivate the pÄramitÄ of patience in order to perfect it? How many kinds of patience are there? If practitioners apply themselves in this way, how should they proceed? I only wish that you would reveal this, as we are eager to hear it.
At that time, the Buddha BhagavÄn praised Maitreya Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
You now wish to benefit and bring peace to all beings, and are able to ask about such profound principles.
Listen carefully now, contemplate it well, and I will now explain it to you in detail.
Good man!
You should know that birth and death, and nirvana, are all equal, without discrimination. This is called the perfection of patience.
Furthermore, if there are foolish, inferior, and insane beings who come to scold and insult, one should patiently endure it.
It is like a drunken elephant that is difficult to restrain. One should use an iron hook to tame it.
The drunken elephant of an angry mind is also like this. Using the hook of patience, one should control and subdue it, causing it to be tamed. This is called the perfection of patience.

Furthermore, if there are sentient beings who are harmed by the thirty-six koá¹­is of heavenly demons, ghosts, spirits, yaká¹£as, and rÄká¹£asas who come to invade the bodhisattva, only the perfection of patience can destroy their armies. Even the eighty-four thousand afflictions and enemies that wish to be subdued are also eliminated by patience.
Not only does one thus subdue the great armies of celestial demons and the enemies of afflictions, but even the most insignificant enemies are subdued through patient acceptance.
This is called the perfection of patient acceptance.

Furthermore, it is like a prince who is well-versed in the royal laws. After the passing of his father, the king, he succeeds to the throne. He should promulgate the correct Dharma to the four directions, and all within the realm will respectfully follow the five kinds of correct Dharma.
What are the five?
First, not taking life; second, not engaging in theft; third, abstaining from sexual misconduct; fourth, not speaking falsely; fifth, not imposing additional taxes and levies on the people.
If there are those who commit murder within the king's realm, the king will incur one-sixth of the offense. Stealing, sexual misconduct, and false speech are also the same.
Why is it so?
If it is Dharma or non-Dharma, the king is the basis. One-sixth of the offenses and merits belong to the king.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. The mind is the country, great compassion is the king, and with the five forbearance dharmas, they proclaim throughout the realm, namely, beating, scolding, anger, ridicule, and so forth. These five dharmas are all peacefully endured. If one violates them, one will incur a great heavy offense.
Furthermore, Maitreya!

It is like when farmers want to plant, in order to divert water, they first dig the ditches. When they begin their work, they may encounter mountain rocks, and there is no way to dig through them, so they stop.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are not like this. In the great wilderness of birth and death, they want to dig the wisdom canal and divert the water of immortality. Having begun their practice, they may encounter the rock of anger, and there is no way to remove it. They only have peaceful forbearance, carefully observe and penetrate it.
Moreover, all kings, ministers, elders, and laypeople always adorn themselves with necklaces, while the Dharma King and great bodhisattvas always adorn their bodies with the necklace of patience.
If they encounter sentient beings who are unjustly deceived, they rescue and protect them with great compassion and patience.
Moreover, this patience serves as a teacher and model for bhiká¹£us and bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s.

Using faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom as the forest, and pure precepts as the branches and leaves, if the fire of anger suddenly arises within this forest and burns the branches and leaves of the precepts, it cannot be extinguished, but can only be extinguished by the rain of patience. In the present and future, all suffering and difficulties will be forever free from worry and trouble.
Those who lack patience will have no peace and joy in the present world, whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, so how could they have happiness in the future world?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas use the power of patience as their armor. Those who commit offenses are like bandits, with their hands of anger holding the bow of false thoughts, shooting the arrow of harsh words at the armor of patience, but that bow and arrow naturally break and the armor of patience is not damaged at all. The broken bow and arrow turn into lotus flowers.
You should know that the bodhisattva's practice like this is called the perfection of patience.
Furthermore, it is like the agada medicine in the world, which can cure all poisons and illnesses of oneself and others.
The bodhisattva is also like this. The agada medicine of patience can cure the poisonous illnesses of anger and afflictions of oneself and others. This is called the perfection of patience.

It is like the bright moon jewel in the world. The caravan leader carries it when traveling through the great wilderness, in the middle of the desert where there is no water. At night, he holds the jewel towards the moon, and the water immediately flows out into the container. The caravan leader drinks it and is able to cross the wilderness.

Bodhisattvas are also like this. Holding this bright moon of patience and forbearance, they cross through the wilderness and deserts of birth and death, where there is no water of wisdom and only afflictions. In the moon of the Buddha's wisdom, they hold the pearl of patience and forbearance, receive the water of the Dharma, and the bodhisattvas drink it, leaving birth and death and reaching the shore of nirvana.
Furthermore, Maitreya!
It is like the great earth, upon which all grasses and trees grow and all sentient beings rely to live.
Patience and forbearance are also like this. All bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate the six perfections in the ten grounds, relying on them to grow and abide.
Furthermore, there is a ladder that is extremely tall, which sentient beings can climb to reach the Brahma Heaven.
The ladder of patience and forbearance is also like this. Bodhisattvas can climb it to reach the Heaven of Heavens.
Furthermore, it is like a skilled painter who paints various images and completes the adornments.
The painter of patience is also like this, perfecting and accomplishing the merit of adornment.

Furthermore, it is like when a great dense cloud arises in the sky, pouring down heavy rain and flooding everything, washing away all grasses, trees, flowers, and fruits, entering the Ganges River and turning to the great ocean.

Bodhisattvas are also like this. The mind is like the sky, able to give rise to the great compassionate dense cloud, pouring down the great Dharma rain of the flood of patience, washing away all the grasses and trees of anger, the flowers and fruits of delusion, flowing into the river of wisdom and turning to the pure great ocean of nirvana.

Furthermore, although bodhisattvas see the suffering of samsara's flow, they use the power of patience to take on the suffering for them, enduring it for countless eons without complaining or giving up, and without attaining nirvana.

Furthermore, by the power of patience, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to give away everything - head, eyes, marrow, brains, body flesh, hands, feet, and even their lives - without any stinginess in their minds.
Ordinary beings, lacking wisdom, are frightened upon hearing this and their body hairs stand on end. How can they abandon it?

Thus, through the power of patience and tolerance, wherever bodhisattvas are reborn, their appearance is upright and proper, and all beings delight in seeing them. In the great assembly, they are always praised by the buddhas.
Furthermore, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the power of patience, firm and unmoving.
Like the majestic Mount Sumeru, which cannot be moved by violent winds swirling around it.
The majestic mountain of patience is also like this, which cannot be moved by the violent winds of anger.

Furthermore, all non-Buddhists, due to evil friends, give rise to the mind of wrong views and practice various austerities - going naked, starving themselves, scorching themselves with the five heats, throwing themselves off cliffs and into fires - claiming to attain rebirth in the heavens, not believing in the true Dharma.

Seeing this, the bodhisattva arouses a mind of great compassion and demonstrates ascetic practices that surpass theirs by a hundredfold. These non-Buddhists revere the bodhisattva as their teacher and model, and then he guides them and shows them the right Dharma, causing those of wrong views to abide in right views.
Again, there are non-Buddhists who say:
This body has a self dwelling in the heart, like a large thumb, unobstructed and formless, only those with the heavenly eye can see it.
And this eye faculty serves the self, and once the eye obtains it, it immediately reports to the self, and so it is with the ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.

For this reason, if there are sentient beings who insult me, those who can kill them will be reborn in the heavens, while those who endure the insults will fall into the three evil paths when they die.
It is like many people working together with a general. If they insult my general, the multitude will kill him together. If they do not kill him, the multitude will be guilty.
The bodhisattva, with the power of forbearance and compassion for those with wrong views, endures all of it, and uses various skillful means to eliminate their wrong views.
It is like timely rain, which can moisten and nourish the growth of grasses and trees according to them, causing them to bear fruit.
The bodhisattva's forbearance is also like this.
At that time, the Blessed One spoke a verse, saying:
Just as when the heavens want to rain, ants leave their nests, gather earth to make mounds as their dwellings,
The body is formed from the impurities of parents, and the deluded consciousness grasps it as the self.
The continuity of form and strength relies on the strong, but the wise contemplate it as illusory and flickering,
In a single thought, it becomeså¾®å¡µ, like an elephant trampling on a mound, all scattering and breaking apart.
In the blink of an eye, it quickly arises and perishes. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, it is all suffering.
If one understands that the physical body is suffering and impermanent, how can the wise one be attached to it?
The practice of the heavens and BrahmÄ abodes, the poison snake cannot harm by sight or touch,
If there is injury, the mantra and medicine can cure, but who can save from the bite of impermanence?
The easy-to-practice good dharmas are all abandoned, the defeated class of desire and pleasure greedily seeks suffering,
The wise observe it to be unaccomplished, like a dirty garment dyed with saffron.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should explain the Dharma of no-self to non-Buddhists:
'The self that you cling to, is it within?
Or is it without?
Does it come from the past?
Or does it go to the future?
If you say it exists, when your life ends it should be able to save you, but since it cannot save you, it is clear that there is no self.
It is like a loyal minister who single-mindedly serves his lord. If he is in danger, the lord will surely save him. Since he cannot save you now, it is certain that there is no self.
If there were a self, it should be able to be in control. Why then is it destroyed by impermanence?

Yet sentient beings are afflicted by the demon of impermanence and various sufferings, their limbs dismembered, and they depart in a daze. If there were a self, one should be able to escape this, but since one cannot escape it, one knows there is no self.
For this reason, you non-Buddhists have served me since beginningless time, created various evil karma, and experienced suffering endlessly.

Know that this self has little kindness. You have served others for a long time, abandoning you and leaving, and have eventually entrusted your body to evil beasts, jackals, wolves, tigers, leopards, and so on, to be eaten. However, I have abandoned you and sought other bodies. From beginningless time, I have abandoned you all, and if one calculates the number, it is immeasurable and boundless. The present and future are also like this.

Furthermore, if you say the mind is the divine self and the body is a servant, know that this body is then possessed by the self. From beginningless time, the bodies experienced are immeasurable, and one does not know their number.
Are these bodies of one self?
Or of many selves?
If the self is many, it is impermanent. Because of impermanence, the meaning of self is not established.
If the self is one, it should be permanent, always guarding one body and should not move away. Because of not abiding, one is also not established.
For this reason, you should contemplate, the meaning of many selves and one self are both not established.
Therefore, you should know that the mind is not the self.
You should further contemplate, the body is not the self's possessions nor its servants.

If the body belongs to the self, in birth, old age, sickness, and death, it should require the self's orders. Before the self gives instructions, they come one after another. It is clear that it does not belong to the self.

If it belongs to the self, birth should always be born and should not age or die. Walking, standing, sitting, and lying down are also like this. Changing and not being permanent, it is definitely not the self's possessions.
By this, you should definitely know that there is no self or that which belongs to the self.
Furthermore, you should know that the grasped self is your great enemy.
Why is it so?

You have accumulated good roots in your past lives, and the rewards of the five desires have been exhausted in this life. You have created various evil karma in the present, and due to the power of karma, you have been handed over to the jailers.
If there is a self, why do you not save each other?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with the power of patient acceptance, rescue sentient beings from the evil ghosts of self and possession, and place them in the position of right view, free from self and possession. Seeing that all dharmas are originally empty and tranquil by nature, this is called the bodhisattva's cultivation of the perfection of patient acceptance.
Furthermore, Maitreya!
It is just like a person who, in order to protect his child, creates spells to prevent evil ghosts from harming them.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. They use the spells of patient acceptance to protect all sentient beings, and the thieves of anger and so forth are unable to harm them.
Furthermore, Maitreya, it is like a person whose foot is pierced by a thorn, wishing to cover the entire earth with leather to walk upon without worry.
A wise person asks:
'What do you seek the skin for, and what do you intend to do with it?'
This person then fully reported the above reasons.
The wise one reprimanded, saying:
'Alas, foolish person!
This is not appropriate.
You only need a little skin to make shoes, enough for traveling without being harmed. Why use so much skin to cover the entire earth?'
Ordinary sentient beings are also like this. They create enemies everywhere and hold knives to kill the enemy of the earth.

The bodhisattva, seeing this, deeply feels compassion. He only uses patience as shoes to protect your body and mind. What enemies would hold knives to harm everywhere? This is called the perfection of patience.

Suppose someone uses poisonous and evil words to revile in various ways. When the bodhisattva hears this, he should not suddenly give rise to an angry mind. He should contemplate:ğŸ”½'Who is the one who reviles like this?
Who is the one who receives the revilement?'

These two bodies each have twelve sense bases - the eye sense base sees forms, the ear sense base hears sounds, the nose sense base smells fragrances, the tongue sense base tastes flavors, the body sense base feels touches, and the mind sense base cognizes dharmas. But this eye sense base is truly not the self. If it is not the self, whose fault is it, of self or other, in the eye sense base?
If there is a fault, it should be punished.
' Thus observing, both are without fault. Since there is no fault, who is reviled and who is angry?
Thus observing, up to the dharma sense base is also like this.
Outside the twelve sense bases, there is not a single thing. The reviler and the reviled are both empty.
By contemplating this, the angry mind suddenly ceases.
If one hears coarse language, one should carefully observe:
'Of such language, which is coarse?
The two words 'coarse language' do not arise simultaneously. When coarse, it is not language; when language, it is not coarse. Arising and ceasing in a moment, each does not wait for the other.
Even two words are non-existent, let alone many insults.
In this way, observing for hundreds of thousands of eons, even coarse words do not constitute insults.
Moreover, observing that the one who insults and the Dharma that is insulted are both impermanent, not abiding for a moment, how can there be anger?

From this it should be known that the past has already ceased, the future has not yet arrived, and the present does not abide. Since the Dharma of insults is empty, my body is also thus, the same as that impermanence, arising and ceasing without abiding. Because of non-abiding, all are empty.
When contemplating in this way, immeasurable enemies and thieves are instantly eliminated.
If one departs from this contemplation and grasps at characteristics and distinctions, it is merely called patient acceptance, and it cannot be called pÄramitÄ.

The five aggregates are without self, up to the eighteen realms and so forth, are all also without self, like illusions and transformations. Insult and praise are equal, the inherent nature is originally empty and tranquil, and it is also like this.
Furthermore, Maitreya!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when seeing those who slander and abuse, should give rise to compassion,
thinking: 'Such people, due to anger, are possessed by MÄra and covered by afflictions, thus slandering and abusing.

I now wish to dispel this MÄra and should skillfully cultivate the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« of patience, not giving rise to anger or resentment, and not allowing anger and other afflictions to harm sentient beings.
If I were to become angry, it would be as if a ghost possessed me.'
For this reason, towards those who slander, they give rise to great compassion and patiently endure it.
Although they are able to do so, it is only called patience. If free from discrimination, it is then called pÄramitÄ.
Furthermore, Maitreya!

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice patience, if they see someone holding a sharp knife cutting off their hands and feet, they should give rise to a joyful mind and think of them as a good and wise advisor, just as someone who gives to others feels delighted and thinks: I have now obtained great blessings and rewards. I will always bear a sense of gratitude towards those who receive [my gifts], and those who see this will all give rise to joy.
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Seeing those who cut and slice [them], they give rise to great joy and comfort:

They remove my karmic offenses and bestow upon me the wealth of the Dharma. Because of me, they accept a bad reputation, lose the bliss of humans, gods, and liberation, and receive the suffering of the three evil paths.
For this reason, they are good friends and good companions for me, helping me perfect the perfection of patience.
I should give rise to respect for them, and even up to enlightenment I will not forget their kindness, let alone give rise to anger instead.
If one gives rise to anger, it is a betrayal of kindness.
For this reason, one should give rise to respect and think of them as a good teacher.
Although one can endure such difficult things, because one has not yet eliminated discrimination regarding oneself and others, it is only called patience, and it is not called pÄramitÄ.
Furthermore, when a bodhisattva abides in a secluded place, if someone comes and slanders the bodhisattva, saying:
'You engage in stealing and sexual misconduct, and you beat, scold, and punish others,'
the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva endures it patiently and thinks like this:
'This is not the fault of others. In my past lives, I have also slandered others, beaten, scolded, and punished them. Because of my remaining bad karma, I have attracted this punishment from them.
Because of this, they will fall into evil destinies. I should give rise to great compassion for this person.'
He further thinks to himself:

'My mind now is extremely deceitful. I am afraid of falling into hell and give rise to a mind of patience. Moreover, I want to accomplish the perfection of patience myself, causing those who cut and slice me to fall into the three evil paths.

Thinking like this, they deeply feel shame and embarrassment. At this time, the bodhisattvas see their own faults and feel ashamed and disgusted towards those who cut them, thinking of them as good and wise teachers, deeply respecting them. This is only called patience, not the perfection of patience.
Why is this?
Because there is discrimination between self and others.
Furthermore, the bodhisattvas understand that the Dharma of anger is the cause of all suffering, and know that practicing patience is the root of myriad practices.
For this reason, they practice patience, which is only called patience, not the perfection of patience.
Why is this?
Because there is discrimination between good and evil.

Furthermore, the bodhisattvas contemplate the five aggregates of the body, which have five kinds of faults, are the accumulation of various sufferings, are momentary and impermanent, are of five kinds of impurity, and consist of thirty-six substances. They are all empty, without self or possessions.
Non-Buddhist wrong views grasp the body as blissful, permanent, unchanging, pure, with self and possessions.
Bodhisattvas contemplate these five kinds of dharmas, and all sentient beings are also like this.
Having understood this, they do not become angry when scolded, and do not rejoice when praised, but are only called patient, not the perfection of patience.
Furthermore, Maitreya!
In brief, the bodhisattvas' patience is of thirty-two kinds.
Namely, non-greed is patience, non-harming is patience, being free from vexation is patience,
being free from anger is patience, being free from resentment is patience, being free from rage is patience,
being free from disputes is patience, not being defiled by sensual desires is patience, being able to protect oneself and others is patience,

being in accord with the mind of enlightenment is patience, having a non-discriminating mind is patience, not being attached to birth and death is patience, being in accord with the fruits of karma is patience, the purity of the body is patience,
the purity of speech and mind is patience, being firm and not retreating is patience, being free in one's speech and action is patience,

This is patience. Being without conceptualization is patience. The self-realized holy wisdom is patience.ğŸ”½Protecting the minds of others is patience. Cultivating the four kinds of pure conduct without being reborn according to meditation is patience.ğŸ”½Obtaining mastery over the pleasures of humans and gods is patience. The perfection of the major and minor marks is patience.ğŸ”½The profound and wonderful Brahma voice is patience. Eliminating all evils is patience. Being far removed from the defilements of stinginess is patience.ğŸ”½

This is patience, being without conceptualization is patience, the self-realized holy wisdom is patience, protecting the minds of others is patience, cultivating the four kinds of brahmavihÄra and not being reborn according to dhyÄna is patience, attaining mastery over the pleasures of humans and gods is patience, perfecting the major and minor marks is patience, the profound and wondrous Brahma voice is patience, eliminating all evils is patience, being free from the defilements of stinginess is patience, cutting off jealousy is patience, abandoning all enmity is patience, approaching the factors of enlightenment is patience, being free from all unwholesomeness is patience, delighting in dwelling in solitude is patience, attaining all the Buddha's teachings is patience.
Maitreya!

In this way, the thirty-two kinds of patience pÄramitÄ, if practiced by bodhisattvas, they will be able to attain the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas and quickly accomplish supreme perfect enlightenment.
Furthermore, Maitreya!
What is called the pÄramitÄ of patience?
If someone verbally abuses you, view that voice as an echo in a valley.
When struck, view this body as a reflection in a mirror.
When angry, view this mind as an illusion.
When seeing anger, view this mind's nature as free from agitation.ğŸ”½When receiving offerings, view this mind's inherent nature as disciplined, not giving rise to joy.
When losing offerings, view this mind as well-tamed and tranquil, not giving rise to anger.
When encountering slander, view this body as empty space, not responding in kind.
When encountering praise, view one's nature as free from arrogance and not becoming conceited.
When receiving compliments, view the mind's nature as originally empty and tranquil, not giving rise to delight.
When being criticized, view the fundamental mind as free from fear, not giving rise to worry.
When encountering suffering, view the nature of phenomena as originally free from oppression, not seeing the characteristics of suffering.
If one experiences pleasure, one should contemplate the true nature, which is eternally abiding and unchanging, without the characteristics of suffering or pleasure.
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in patience, these eight kinds of adverse conditions cannot move them.
Why is this?
Because the mind of enlightenment abides in the true characteristics, free from the views of self and other, and sees the Dharma body.
Moreover, one endures all unfavorable things in order to subdue the mÄras and adversaries.
One should practice all difficult and painful practices in order to subdue the non-Buddhist paths and various wrong views.
Maitreya!
You should know that I have now briefly explained the perfection of patience.
Furthermore, Maitreya!ğŸ”½If one contemplates impermanence and is free from the characteristics of self and other, the mind attains patience, but it is not true patience.
If one contemplates the characteristics of good and bad dharmas, the mind attains patience, but it is not true patience.
If one observes the forbearance of the twelve sense bases, and attains forbearance in the separation from anger and scolding of the faculties and objects, it is not true forbearance.
If one observes anger and scolding as inverted, and forbearance as true,
Discerning the forbearance of the right and wrong, it is not true forbearance.
Furthermore, seeing forbearance as reasonable and anger and scolding as unreasonable, this grasping at characteristics forbearance is not true forbearance.
Furthermore, abiding in the eight correct forbearances and leaving the eight wrong forbearances, the forbearance of the path and non-path, is not true forbearance.

Furthermore, not observing the forbearance of impermanence, no-self, impurity, and suffering of all dharmas, but only observing the forbearance of the permanence, bliss, self, and purity of all dharmas, the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, this contradictory forbearance is not true forbearance.

Furthermore, the forbearance of empty dharmas, the non-forbearance of various views;ğŸ”½The forbearance of signless dharmas, the non-forbearance of having signs;ğŸ”½The forbearance of wishless dharmas, the non-forbearance of having wishes;
The forbearance of unconditioned dharmas, the non-forbearance of having conditioning;
The acceptance of the Dharma free from afflictions, but not accepting the Dharma with afflictions;
The acceptance of wholesome dharmas, but not accepting unwholesome dharmas;
The acceptance of supramundane dharmas, but not accepting mundane dharmas;ğŸ”½The acceptance of faultless dharmas, but not accepting dharmas with faults;
The acceptance of uncontaminated dharmas, but not accepting contaminated dharmas;
The acceptance of nirvÄá¹‡a, but not accepting saá¹ƒsÄra.
These kinds of acceptance are counteractive acceptance, not ultimate acceptance.
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
If such acceptance is not ultimate, what is called ultimate acceptance?
I only pray that the TathÄgata will explain it in detail.
At that time, the Blessed One told Maitreya Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva:
Good man!

The true forbearance is to realize with right wisdom that the inherent nature of all dharmas is originally empty, and this emptiness is non-dual with all dharmas, therefore the inherent nature of all dharmas, the inherent nature of emptiness, and the inherent nature of right wisdom are originally pure, non-dual, without distinction, and without interruption.
Therefore, one should know that worldly dharmas are emptiness, and emptiness is worldly dharmas, because the inherent nature of the two dharmas is not separate.
Such forbearance is called ultimate forbearance.

Furthermore, with right wisdom one realizes that the inherent nature of all dharmas is originally without inherent nature, and the inherent nature without inherent nature is all dharmas, because the inherent nature of all dharmas is originally non-dual.
The inherent nature of all dharmas originally without inherent nature and the inherent nature of right wisdom are originally pure, non-dual, without distinction, and without interruption.
Therefore, one should know that all dharmas are originally without characteristics, and the absence of characteristics is all dharmas, because the inherent nature of the two dharmas is not separate.
Such forbearance is called ultimate forbearance.

Furthermore, with right wisdom one understands that the nature of all dharmas is the nature of non-aspiration, and the nature of non-aspiration is the nature of all dharmas. The fundamental nature is non-dual.
The nature of non-aspiration and the nature of all dharmas are the fundamental nature of right wisdom, which is pure, non-dual, without distinction, and unbroken.
Therefore, one should know that all dharmas are non-aspiration, and non-aspiration is all dharmas. The fundamental nature of the two dharmas is inseparable.
Such acceptance is called ultimate acceptance.

Furthermore, with right wisdom one understands that the nature of all conditioned activities is the nature of non-conditioned activity. This nature of non-conditioned activity and the nature of all conditioned activities are fundamentally non-dual.
The nature of all conditioned activities and the nature of non-conditioned activity are the fundamental nature of right wisdom, which is pure, non-dual, without distinction, and unbroken.
Up to such acceptance is ultimate acceptance.

Furthermore, using right wisdom to understand that the nature of afflictions is itself the nature of non-afflictions, and the nature of non-afflictions is itself the nature of afflictions, because the fundamental nature is non-dual.
The nature of afflictions and the nature of non-afflictions are fundamentally pure in the nature of right wisdom, without duality or division, without distinction or interruption.
Up to this kind of forbearance is ultimate forbearance.

Furthermore, using right wisdom to understand that the nature of all wholesome dharmas is itself the nature of unwholesome dharmas, and the nature of unwholesome dharmas is itself the nature of all wholesome dharmas, because the fundamental nature is non-dual.
The nature of wholesomeness and the nature of unwholesomeness are fundamentally pure in the nature of right wisdom, without duality or division, without distinction or interruption.
Up to this kind of forbearance is ultimate forbearance.

Furthermore, using right wisdom to understand that the nature of supramundane dharmas is itself the nature of mundane dharmas, and the nature of mundane dharmas is itself the nature of supramundane dharmas, because the fundamental nature is non-dual.
The nature of supramundane dharmas and the nature of mundane dharmas are originally pure by right wisdom, without duality or division, without distinction or interruption.
Up to this kind of patience, it is ultimate patience.
